title: I Didn’t Want to Do More With My Time. I Wanted to Do Better.
html:

I Didn’t Want to Do More With My Time. I Wanted to Do Better.

Guillaume Grassiant
Apr 2

This post is about my experience with Make Time and how it improved my routine (see “Routine does not mean boring”). Thanks to John Zeratsky and Jake Knapp for helping me write and edit this text and also for giving me the opportunity to chat about time :)

I recently read that after pretty thorough research, scientists came to the conclusion that time travel, or at least time travel machines, would probably never exist. At least not anytime soon. That was a bit of a bummer for me since I’ve always been obsessed with time and how to do more things I liked with it.

I haven’t always been successful at making good use of my time. I never learned to code because I felt I didn’t have enough time, and anyway, I was too old. I never started my getting-back-into-shape project, because you know, with work and stuff, “ain’t nobody got time for that.” I struggled at the office, too, where I was so responsive to my colleagues and my clients that I never had time for the work that was important to me. I had a well-optimized work routine, but it wasn’t helping me spend time on my priorities.

Then came along “Sprint”. It was early 2018, I was on vacation with my family, and I bought this book because a friend of mine told me it would change the way I approach projects. Not because It’s magical, but because it structures time in an efficient manner and with a key idea: constraints cut the fat and help you to focus on what matters. I loved it.

That’s when I started to follow John and Jake, read their Time Dorks newsletter, and read other people’s work such Basecamp’s “It Doesn’t Have to Be Crazy at Work”. All that set me in the mood for “Make Time”. As soon as it came out, I bought it and devoured it.

This book helped me realize that I didn’t want to do more with my time — I wanted to do better.

What I immediately appreciated about “Make Time” is that it did not feel like this was the method you had to follow. It’s not a scathing criticism of what the world has become because of technology. It just feels like an honest pit stop in life, to reflect on what’s taking up too much of our precious time and not allowing us to do things we like. And that last part varies from one person to another. I totally related to that as a 30-something-going-on-40 guy, working in the digital sphere. I had to make a change, I had to make time to start all these “someday” projects today. This book helped me realize that I didn’t want to do more with my time — I wanted to do better.

My Favorite Make Time Tactics

I used the tactics in the book to choose my daily Highlights. Thanks to Stack Rank Your Life (tactic #3) I created four buckets for my possible Highlights:

  • Life: Includes all personal projects.
  • Work: Tasks I need to complete but also every feedback or interaction my team and clients expect from me.
  • Wealth: Wealthy from a general perspective. Not just finances but also volunteering, etc. Feeling rich in experiences.
  • Tribe: Everything family and relationships.

I also created a “kitchen sink” full of might-do items I call “Nice to Haves” (#5). I also started designing my days (#13) and making time for my highlights (#8).

Next, I made sure I was spending each day laser-focused on my priorities. I got rid of almost all apps and notifications on my phone. I started to steer clear from infinity pools and take back control of emails. I also started to make sure that I get my daily dose of exercise, eat healthily, and spend time with loved ones.

As the last step, I reflect each day. How is this working for me? What can I adjust? I started crafting a gentle reminder of what I need to always have as a basis in my day-to-day. My biggest highlight this year is getting back into coding, so I want to make sure that’s a part of every day.

I called this the Pyramid of Happiness. It’s a simple drawing I keep in my journal and I make sure I regularly look at it to keep me on track.

At the base, I wrote down what’s mandatory every day. For me, that’s waking up early to accomplish three things:

  • 10 minutes of meditation
  • 5 minutes of writing in my journal
  • 30 to 40 minutes of exercise (running or gym)

It has to happen. Every day. It sets the tone for the rest of the day. Even during the weekends. (With a little twist for Saturday: add to this reading the weekly newspaper when having coffee.)

Next up is the highlight. Just one. It also is mandatory. Between 60 and 90 minutes every day. And pro-tip, if you wake up early enough you can squeeze 45 of those minutes after the 3-step basis! If you are a night owl, well it works too. Just apply the Pyramid after dark.

Finally, like any good recipe, you need a topping. That’s when I choose one to three (depending on the day) items from the Nice-to-Have list. And if I accomplish none of them, well I don’t feel bad. That’s just the topping.

So that’s it, the Pyramid of Happiness. A simple reminder of what sets the day correctly to make sure I focus on the right things. Not to do more, but to do better with my time.

  • Productivity
  • Methodology
  • Time

  • Guillaume Grassiant

    I love my wife, my parents, my friends, dogs, music, running, soccer, football, video games, travels, coding & digital products. https://github.com/gozoslash

  • The old noob

    How trying to do less made me do better. The blog of a 30 going on 40 guy wanting to learn how to code and make a better use of his time. Avatar by Catkuro: https://www.flaticon.com/authors/catkuro
